questions.question_text_1: THIS IS QUESTION PAPER FOR THE SUBJECT "DEGREE LEVEL :ADVANCED ALGORITHMS (COMPUTER BASED EXAM)" ARE YOU SURE YOU HAVE TO WRITE EXAM FOR THIS SUBJECT? questions.question_text_1:
Consider the given problem, called BoxDepth: Given a set of n axis-aligned rectangles in the plane, how big is the largest subset of these rectangles that contain a common point? 
For each statement given in the subquestions, determine if it is true or false.
question_texts:
Consider the given problem, called BoxDepth: Given a set of n axis-aligned rectangles in the plane, how big is the largest subset of these rectangles that contain a common point? 
For each statement given in the subquestions, determine if it is true or false.

questions.question_text_1: There is a polynomial-time reduction from BoxDepth to MaxClique.
question_texts: There is a polynomial-time reduction from BoxDepth to MaxClique.

questions.question_text_1: Suppose your friend comes up with an algorithm to solve Partition in time O(nM), where n is the size of the input set and M is the sum of the absolute values of its elements. Which of the following statements is correct?
question_texts: Suppose your friend comes up with an algorithm to solve Partition in time O(nM), where n is the size of the input set and M is the sum of the absolute values of its elements. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.option_text: Such an algorithm cannot be possibly correct, since it runs in polynomial timeand Partition is NP-hard.
Even if such an algorithm exists, then it does not imply that P=NP.

questions.question_text_1:
The problem AllOrNothing3Sat asks, given a 3CNF boolean formula, whether there is an assignment to the variables such that each clause either has three True literals or has three False literals. 
Consider the following statements: (1) There is a polynomial-time algorithm to solve AllOrNothing3Sat.  (2) There is a polynomial-time reduction from 3SAT to AllOrNothing3Sat. 
Assuming P ≠ NP, which of the following is true?
question_texts:
The problem AllOrNothing3Sat asks, given a 3CNF boolean formula, whether there is an assignment to the variables such that each clause either has three True literals or has three False literals. 
Consider the following statements: (1) There is a polynomial-time algorithm to solve AllOrNothing3Sat.  (2) There is a polynomial-time reduction from 3SAT to AllOrNothing3Sat. 
Assuming P ≠ NP, which of the following is true?

options.option_text: Statement (1) is true and statement (2) is false.
Statement (1) is false and statement (2) is true.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statements is true about a flow network?
question_texts: Which of the following statements is true about a flow network?

options.option_text: Increasing the capacity of one edge (u,v) by 1 can result in an increase of atmost 1 in the max flow.
Increasing the capacity of one edge (u,v) by 1 will result in an increase of atleast 1 in the max flow.
Decreasing the capacity of one edge (u,v) by 1 can result in a decrease of atmost 1 in the max flow.
Decreasing the capacity of one edge (u,v) by 1 will result in a decrease of atleast 1 in the max flow.

questions.question_text_1: Given a flow network (G, s, t, c) and a flow f, how will you determine if f is maximum flow?
question_texts: Given a flow network (G, s, t, c) and a flow f, how will you determine if f is maximum flow?

options.option_text: If there is any edge that is not saturated to full capacity, then we can concludethat f is not a maximum flow.
If the residual graph does not have any augmenting paths then f is amaximum flow.
If the value of the flow f is not the sum of the capacities of the edges comingout of the source s then f is not a maximum flow.
If the value of the flow f is not the sum of the capacities of the edges cominginto the sink t then f is not a maximum flow.

questions.question_text_1:
In this question, we consider a card game called SWISH. 
In the commercial version of SWISH, there are 60 transparent cards. Those cards are made up of three columns and four rows, they are obtained by placing a point in each ofthe four possible positions (accounting for symmetries), and then a circle in each of the other possible positions. Some example cards are shown below.

Suppose the randomly assigned weights lead to the good event, that is, there is an unique perfect matching in G with minimum weight, and say this minimum weight is r. What can you say about the determinant of Z in this case?
